original_title: Sri Lanka Speaker says courts have no jurisdiction on intervene on DDR
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s speaker Mahinda Abeywardana announcing a ruling on parliamentary privileges said courts in the island have no jurisdiction to intervene on domestic debt restructuring resolution which has been passed in parliament.
There are at least two petitions in the Supreme Court alleging that restructuring debt in the Employees Provident Fund and limiting it to pension funds while excluding others holders is iniquitous.

The restructuring plan was approved by the parliaments committee with a majority and passed by the parliament on July 01, with 122 members voting for and 62 against and it was a matter concerning public finance.

“As the resolution for the implementation of domestic debt optimization to restore sovereign debt sustainability has been passed by parliament on 01.07.2023 the resolution is beyond the jurisdiction Supreme Court or any other court established under 171 constitution of Sri Lanka and cannot be questioned, and/or reviewed and/or challenged,” Speaker Abeywardana told parliament.
He cited a previous ruling by former Speaker Anura Bandaranaike that speaker cannot be restrained by interim court orders and a law on parliamentary privileges.
Abeywardana was responding to ruling requested by Minister Harin Fernando whether courts could intervene on the debt restructure.
Related Ruling sought from Sri Lanka Speaker on Supreme Court hearings on DDR

Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa protested that citizens had the right to go to court on fundamental  rights according to the constitution because bond holders had been treated unequally in the debt restructure plan. (Colombo/Aug09/2023)
